title: Can we communicate or deliver information via quantum entanglement? - Quora

response.answer_text: Short answer is that it is not possible because quantum entanglement acts over any distance instantaneously, so having an ability to transfer information by means of any quantum state (entangled, mixed or pure) would allow for information to be transmitted faster than light. Luckily, relativity is not violated because it is not in fact possible to transmit information using quantum entanglement. I will do my best to explain why. One of the most puzzling aspects of quantum entanglement is the principle of non-locality. An entangled state represented by the spins of two atoms, for instance, can theoretically be maintained even once you separate them by a large distance (even billions of light years). Thus measuring one of the atomic spins immediately determines the spin of the other, regardless of how far away it is. This behavior, which Einstein dismissively called “spooky action at a distance,” led many scientists to look for hidden variable theories to explain quantum phenomena. Furthermore, the two atoms interact directly with one another, rather than intermediately through the various media separating them; this contradicts our habitual understanding of how the universe works. When people talk about using quantum entanglement for faster-than-light communication, what they really want to do is take one of the two entangled particles and perform a measurement that “forces” it to be in a particular state. For instance, imagine if two maximally entangled ions are generated in the following entangled state and one is given to Alice and the other is given to Bob: |Φ+⟩=12√(|0⟩A⊗|0⟩B+|1⟩A⊗|1⟩B)|Φ+⟩=12(|0⟩A⊗|0⟩B+|1⟩A⊗|1⟩B) Where 0 represents spin down and 1 represents spin up. This can be interpreted to mean that both ions are in the same spin, but weather that spin is up or down can only be determined by measuring. To transmit a binary 1 to Bob, Alice would perform some operation on her ion that would force it to be in a spin up state. Thus Bob could instantaneously measure his ion and find that it is also in a spin up state. The problem is that she cannot force it to be in her chosen direction without breaking the entanglement. Since we are using ions, Alice could use a Raman transition to ensure that her ion is in spin up state, but by doing so the entanglement would be broken; Bob’s ion would still be in a superposition of spin up and spin down. This operation is not just a measurement, since the outcomes of quantum measurements are necessarily random. Physicists have also thought of other more creative ways to “force” the result of a measurement. One way would be for Alice to perform a measurement on the particle asking “are you in state 0 or 1 ?” when she wants to transmit bit 0, and perform a different measurement asking ”Are you in 0+1 or 0-1 ?” when she wants to transmit bit 1. The former would result in Bob’s ion being in 0 or 1 with 100% probability, while the later would result in a 50–50 mix of 0 and 1. Since we cannot distinguish between these two scenarios by taking a single measurement, Bob would need a lot of copies of his state in order to determine weather a 0 or 1 was transmitted by Alice. However, the no-cloning theorem tells us that it is impossible to make copies of a quantum state unless you already know what it is. So, in the end both Alice and Bob both have a random string of zeros and ones which only turn out to be perfectly correlated once they get back together and compare them later. In quantum teleportation, this comparison is done by means of a classical communication channel. In this case, Alice makes a “pairity” measurement of her ion (measures if it’s spin is the same or opposite as a known ion, lets say it is in spin up) and transmits the result to bob over this classical channel. If the spins were the same, Bob directly performs a measurement and gets that his ion is also in spin up. If Alice tells him that the spins were opposite, Bob first reverses the spin of his ion then takes a measurement. The key point here is that even thought the quantum state is “teleported” instantaneously (it exists with Alice up until she measures it, at which point Bob has it), the classical communication channel limits the speed at which information can be passed between the two parties to the speed of light in an optical fiber, for instance. So it is only possible to transmit information by using a classical communication channel as well. There are still practical applications where both a classical and quantum channel are used, such as in quantum key distribution where the no-cloning theorem provides absolute security in distributing random cryptographic keys. For a more rigorous, mathematical derivation of why information can’t be transferred using only quantum states, look at the No-commuication theorem.

We have to be very careful with this and understand what we mean by the term “deliver” information. To transfer information between Alice and Bob, the simplest way is for Alice to create a bit of information (e.g. a binary 1 or 0) and send it across to Bob. For there to be real information transfer, Bob MUST NOT be able to predict what Alice is going to send. Information theory calls this (by analogy) a high entropy state. But he must be able to accurately determine WHAT Alice has actually sent once she sends it, even if he cannot predict ahead of time what it was going to be. So he must have a high certainty that any change he observes is due to the agreed protocol that Alice and Bob agreed to upfront and that it is accurately transmitted with low error. So how could entanglement be used to communicate? Well, there are two ways. First is transmission of the particles. To communicate, Alice generates a “1” particle and the entanglement guarantees that a partner particle which is also a “1” is sent over to Bob. So assuming that Bob knows the channel distortion with some accuracy, he can then determine what Alice sent. Now some people may say that this is no different than Alice just sending HER “1” particle over a calibrated channel. Thats not true. At the quantum level, Alice can now test what particle she actually sent without destroying that information on Bob’s particle. That sounds very good. But there is a problem. In some cases, the quantum theory cannot establish that entanglement has actually occurred until both ends have received the particle pair, measured them, and then compared notes….. and that is clearly useless for a communication channel. There is no other way to know for sure that the particles WERE entangled . If Alice generated both particles and tests them for entanglement before sending the second particle to Bob, then unfortunately the quantum measurement process will not preserve the entanglement beyond the measurement process. She would destroy the entanglement! A second way to potentially communicate is for Alice to create a large pool of “1” particles and “0” particles and, ahead of time, send the entangled partners over to Bob. When Alice wants to communicate, she performs some pre-agreed operation on one of her particles, and in theory, Bob should suddenly see one of his particles change state. Its not clear from the theory whether this is really possible since for low error rate Alice has to be sure that the particles received by Bob are indeed in the correct state! And if she did this, at the quantum level, she would destroy the entanglement! Also, for every bit of information to be transmitted to Bob, Alice first has to send the entangled partner to Bob before she communicates. Alice then changes one of her bits and then Bob should in theory see his entangled bit changing, and he can then determine whether it was a “1” or “0” sent by Alice. Not exactly a practical system. So, although I believe it is “in theory” possible to dream up a way to communicate with entangled particles, I still have not seen a practical way for it to be implemented in a “real” system.

I am not sure I understand what you are asking. If you are asking can we send entangled relationships through a communication channel I don’t know. But if you are asking can entangled information assist in transmitting information, there is a very interesting thought experiment. It is called the GHZ paradox. https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~cleve/courses/F11CS667/Lec19Qip09.pdf It is possible to play a game involving 3 people which they cannot always win without using entangled qubits but which then can always win using them. Centrally the game depends on the three players providing an answer which displays evidence of them collaborating to arrive at it, while being too far away from each other to communicate before the answer is required to be given. (They are each further away from each other being at the points of an equilateral triangle than they are from the referee at the center of that triangle). A referee sends out three bits one to each player. The game requires that the referee arranges that either all three bits are 0 or just two are 1. Each player can create any function they like to generate their answer given the input they’ve just received (a 1 or a 0). They then send their three answers independently back to the referee. They win if their three answers has no 1’s in it or 2 1’s and 1 zero in it when the referee sent out three zero bits, but one 1 or three 1’s in it otherwise. No player sees any bit but their own so can’t know if three zero bits have been sent out, and no player sees what other players send back so can’t know if they should send back a 0 or a 1. But they can each use one of three entangled qubits (also sent to them by the referee) to ensure that all three always give the right answer. It behaves like a cheat sheet making the unknowable answer knowable. So entanglement can assist communication when there is no communication.

One of the common misconceptions about entanglement is that it can be used to communicate (i.e. send information) faster than the speed of light. This has been proven to be false: see No-communication theorem for formal proof. What entanglement tells us is that, in the physical reality emerging from QM, two measurements at any distance in space and time can have correlated results without the need for any causal connection between them. Pls, pay attention to the last sentence (“without the need for any causal connection”) which means actually two different things; No transmission of any information occurs from the first measurement to the secondThere was no previous interaction between the two particles that may have lead to an even hidden configuration so that the properties being measured were somehow already set (though not knowable) before the measurementsThese two points are indeed both very important. In fact, when the entanglement was revealed to the world as a fundamental property of QM by Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen with the famous EPR paradox, only point 1 was clear. Indeed, the work of Einstein & Co. aimed mainly at using that point to argue that QM was not complete so that point 2 could not be true (i.e. the properties being measured had to have already their values set ahead of the experiment, even if QM was not able to tell these values). It was then only with Bell's theorem that it was proved that also point 2 holds up. After this little historical excursion, let’s go back to the question. The supposed argument in favor of the possibility to transmit information between two observers (say Alice and Bob) by means of the entanglement is that one of the two observers (say Alice) is supposed to be able to prepare her measurement apparatus in such a way that her measurement can just give a certain well-defined value as outcome, thus constraining the outcome that Bob may get from his measurement to a well-defined value as well. Therefore, Bob may deduce the preparation done by Alice from the measured value (i.e. Alice would have somehow sent that information to Bob). Well, this argument is incorrect as shown by the aforementioned No-communication theorem. In a few words, the theorem proves that there is no preparation that Alice can put in place so that such preparation may be detected by Bob with a measurement. This, of course, under the condition that neither Alice nor Bob took part in the preparation of the initial entangled state of the two particles. In this latter case, of course, either Alice or Bob could have easily encoded a message in the entangled state itself (such information, however, would not be sent at the act a measurement but, rather, would be hardly encoded in the system of the two particles since the preparation of the entanglement). So, in conclusion, entanglement cannot be used to transmit information from Alice to Bob or vice-versa. What Alice and Bob can do is just to run their experiments and then to meet and show to each other their outcomes, thus realizing with their eyes that the values measured by the first are correlated with those measured by the other so that entanglement is true.

Now we know that if Bob measures his and finds “spin up” that Alice's when measured will now show “spin down” Likewise we know that if Bob measures and finds “spin down” over on Mars Alice will find “spin-up” if she measures it. (That IF is important) Now let's assume that Alice is lonely on Mars, and is considering killing herself, but just can't decide. Back on Earth, before leaving for Mars, Alice found herself concerned that melancholy would overcome her and so Alice told Bob, “if I see “spin down” I am going to kill myself. This is a very fine point and kind of feels like a kid trying to talk their way out of trouble, but it is SUPER important. —�—�—�—�—�—�— Now, this may feel wrong to you. You are not alone. It often feels wrong to me. But we are confusing information, knowledge, human experience and reality and applying it to a very specific definition of Information. Here is my troubled non physics logic: To me it seems that if Alice measured her photo at the exact moment Bob did, saw her spin as “down” and killed her self not with a laser gun but by blowing up Mars that this would all happen nearly instantaneously if the whole process was automated with triple redundant systems. And than while it may take time for the light of the explosion or gravitational effects of a planet vanishing to reach Earth that it doesn't matter. Alice died instantly. I just learned about it later. But that is not how information is defined in physics. Basically until we can know for SURE by direct and not indirect data that Alice is dead, no information has been transferred. Essentially humans every day make decisions based on “information” which is really just a hint, or a suggestion of something happening, and we act on it. Physics is far more precise. Quantum entanglement doesn't transmit information. When you have two experimenters (usually called Alice and Bob) doing widely-separated experiments on entangled particles, each of them does a separate experiment on each particle. For example if the entangled particles are photons with opposite polarizations, each experimenter must decide whether to analyze the polarization as horizontal/vertical, or one-or-the-other 45º diagonal, or left/right circularly polarized. What Alice and Bob get from these experiments in their own labs are completely random lists of orientations (horizontal, +45º, horizontal, right-circular, vertical, –45º, etc.). It's only when Alice and Bob compare notes later — using a classical communication channel, like a telephone — that they can determine whether there was entanglement or not. Alice and Bob must compare notes to determine which measurements they made using the same basis. If Alice determined that her 47th photon was horizontally polarized, and Bob determined that his 47th photon was right-circular polarized, those two measurements are completely uncorrelated and carry zero information. However, if Alice determined that her 48th photon was horizontally polarized, and Bob measured his photon in a horizontal/vertical basis, then Alice knows (assuming a high-fidelity experiment, low noise, etc.) that Bob's 48th photon must have come out vertically polarized. This is great for encryption! It lets Alice share innocuous information (her detector orientations) over an insecure communication channel, so that Bob suddenly knows secret information (a random subset of Alice's measurement results) about Alice's lab. Even better for encryption, if a third party (Eve, the eavesdropper) tries to "steal" the secret information by measuring Bob's photons en route, the entanglement is destroyed in a detectable way. But Alice can't control her measurement results to send information to Bob. Even if Alice and Bob agree in advance on the pattern of measurements they will make, e.g. "always horizontal/vertical" or "diagonal every third time," the polarization results in Alice's lab are still random. She can know what Bob is getting, but cannot send him a message. The philosophically interesting part of quantum entanglement is even more subtle. If Alice and Bob measure their polarizations in different but not orthogonal bases — for example, Alice measures horizontal/vertical and Bob measures linear polarization at 22.5º rather than at 45º — then quantum mechanics predicts more correlation than any classical theory. But from your perspective I think just means that even more measurements are required to determine whether entanglement is present or not. In order to transmit information you must also have a classical communication channel.

Great question! Short answer: No. With this answer, we will demonstrate that quantum entanglement does NOT mean there is communication between entangled particles. We will demonstrate this by looking at what happens with filter polarization. Introduction to Quantum Entanglement The majority of readers may not be familiar with important details of what entanglement is and so we will start with a short introductory to quantum entanglement experiments. Feel free to skip this section if you are familiar with entanglement experiments and how they are performed. The majority of Quantum Entanglement experiments are done with photons, so we will focus on photons in this answer, but the same principles apply to entangled electrons, atoms or even molecules. Here is how an experiment is carried out: A quantum entanglement experiment begins by preparing two entangled photons.An excited atom or molecule over a given time interval will release a photon when it's electron drops down a shell.This photon is then split using a silver screen.Both photons may then be stored in a device.Finally, both photons are measured with a polarized filter at precisely the same time in different locations(or they can be measured at integer intervals of the photons' frequency). Syncing both measurements must take into account special and General Relativity, as applicable.The experiment will measure the photons' polarizations at random angles and then compare results.Results will tend to be correlated according to Bell's inequality: So that sums up the majority of entanglement experiments. Now let's look at one often overlooked fact. Polarized Filter Experiments Explain Correlation without Causation Just because both photons tend to be slightly more correlated does NOT mean the photons communicated to each other. Let me demonstrate exactly why this is the case. Consider two polarized filters. If we take a left-right oriented filter and an up-down filter, we block all light from passing through.  But if we insert a 45° filter between them, some light gets through.  Here is a short video demonstrating the same:  Light is a wave. Even if it's polarized up and down, some will still go through a 45° filter and become oriented in that new direction. So in our entanglement experiment, we have to acknowledge that some of that light getting through our measurement filter was reoriented to the angle of measurement. This exactly accounts for the difference between classical and quantum correlation in Bell's inequality. And no communication was necessary for the light to reorient itself when using polarized filters in the above demonstration. Likewise, when a photon reorients itself in an entanglement experiment, this does not prove Bell's Inequality arises from communication between the two photons. “So why do I see articles about Quantum Communication?” When scientists are talking about using quantum correlation for communication, they are referring to encryption for security measures. They are not referring to transmitting information faster than the speed of light. Here's how it works: I send you, say, 1,000 entangled photons to which I have their matching pairs.I also send you, via classical means(i.e. the internet, radio, etc.), an encrypted message using the measured orientation of my photons as the encryption key.You decrypt the message with your photons as the counter key.No one between can hack the message unless they first read your photons, rendering them useless, because they can only be measured once. You can know they were already measured if the message cannot be decrypted.So the answer is No, we cannot communicate through Quantum Entanglement. That's because no information travels between entangled particles. I hope this helps unravel some of the myths surrounding entanglement. If you found this answer helpful, please upvote and thank you for reading!

One thing that is agreed upon is you cannot send information using quantum entaglement at least not quantum entanglement alone. However information is transferred from one location to another but the information is entirely random. If we both have one of two entangled particles and I observe mine and you observe yours and we do it such that the observations are parallel we will both observe opposite states. No one anywhere else can know what these states are except you and I. However I have no control over which state I observe so I also have no control over which state you observer therefore information is transferred but it is random. Suppose I sequentially send you 10 bits and I tell you to number them 1–10 and I number mine 1–10. I then observe the 10 particles I have and see a series something like 0100110111. I know at this point that when you observer yours you will see 1011001000. Now suppose I want to send you the hexadecimal 9, which would be 1001. I can send you the numbers 2–1–3–5 for example (numbering my binary digits from left to right as 1–10). You would then pick from your string of binary numbers 0110 and invert them to 1001 which is hex for 9. Nobody in the entire world would know what number I have transmitted to you except you and me. So the information would be totally secure. A third party can know the address but not the content. This requires two separate transmissions, one via entanglement and the other via ordinary means. Therefore information is not being sent at faster than the speed of light. So that is an idea for a way of using entanglement to send encrypted data safely. Of course the address has a pattern but if the data pool is very large and the addresses are randomly selected it should be possible to transmit data in utter secrecy.

Rules for Quantum entanglement that prohibit faster than light communications: If two observers make the same measurement on quantumly entangle particles they will always measure the same result.If two observers make orthonormal different measurements on quantum entangle particles they will only obtain the results as if the particles were not quantum entangled.Note: For mixed measurements the same results the component common axis to both measurement the distribution or results will match requirement 1 for the common axis and the component along the orthogonal to that axis will match requirement 2. Can we Prove these rules? The problem is, how can one ever possibly prove those rules are always true? Quite simply you can’t. But Occams Razor tells us to assume these assumptions are true so long as experimental data supports these assumptions. Simplest Computer Model If you wanted to reproduce these two simple models in a computer model, you could simply at the time of interaction, assign what the results be of all possible measurements. Then when a particle is measured, you make new random assignments for the orthonormal values for the next measurement. It works and could be used to model absolutely every experiment I know of. Requires absolutely no changing values of other particles and waves being simulated when one wave is measured. That is not to say this is the way quantum mechanics works, but is one example of following these rules that definitely does not allow spooky action at a distance or faster than light communications. Learning Secret Data As long as these rules hold true you cannot transmit information faster than the speed of light. That does not mean you can’t become aware of the meaning of information you already have at the same time as someone else at the very same instance. Lets say for example you have the qubit quantumly entangled in two separate storage devices A & B. From some central location C, you transmit a single which indicates which orthogonormal measurement should be made on that qubit. Both quantum computers receive that signal at the same time, and both proceed to measure the exact same value. Now the owners of both quantum computers despite their separation, learned the same secret at the same time, even though no one else in the universe has become aware of that secret. You have learned that we can become aware secret data instantly regardless of separation in space-time. But can we learn instantly about the decisions on the measurements? Triple Quantum Entanglement Scenarios Lets consider triple quantum entanglement. Most of these experiements are thought experiments at this point because triple quantum entanglement is very difficult to achieve.[1] So we have three photons A, B, and C all separated by an arbitrary amount of space-time distance. What happens if I use the same measurement on all of them? Well of course the answer is I get the same experimental results. Now lets say I make the same measurement on A & B, but an orthonormal measurement on C. Do I still get the same results for both A & B? The answer is I MUST. Lets say measuring C caused A & B to give different results 50% of the time. Then 50% of the time I could instantly detect someone choice to make an orthogonal measurement on C. It turns out this would be true regardless how far away C was when the measurement was made, and regardless if the measurement was made in the past or the future. So the measurement of C cannot break the quantum entanglement between A & B. Now there is one other scenario to consider. What if I measure A & B at the same time in orthonormal measurements. Is C entangled with A or B? (This technique is considered quantum compression.) We learned above that measuring C could not break the entanglement between A & B. So likewise if I make the same measurements on C as I did for A, I should receive the same results as A. The measurement of B could not break that entanglement. If I make the same measurement on C as I did for B, then I should receive the same results as for B. The measurement of A cannot break that quantum entanglement. This argument hold true regardless if we measure C in the past of measurements A & B, in the future of measurements A & B, very far away, or very close to where I measure A & B. Ultimately, quantum entanglement tells me what to expect when I later compare the measurements. However, quantum entanglement does not tell me anything about what the distant experimenter chooses to measure until I can compare those results. We never learn about choices made faster than that information can be communicated by traditional means. That is what we mean when we say information cannot be communicated faster than the speed of light. Delayed Choice Quantum Eraser If you think this makes sense, then I suggest reviewing: Delayed choice quantum eraser - Wikipedia If you truly understand what they are talking about you will have to rethink through this several times to reconcile how a quantum eraser, or a delayed quantum eraser can really work with my two simple rules. To me the simplest explanation is we don’t have coherent waves coming from each slit. So of course on the left, I see no diffraction pattern, as the in phase pattern is precisely shifted with the out of phase pattern to create no net diffraction pattern. However, depending on where a photon shows up on screen tells us something about the probability the waves are in phase or out of phase. Say D1 is triggered primarily when the waves are in phase, and D2 is primarily out of phase. Then R1 ( the diffraction data that triggered D1 ) will primarily show the in phase pattern, and R2 out of phase pattern. Since the measurement of in phase v.s. out of phase must be the same for both entangled photons, we reveal the diffraction pattern. If on the other hand D3 or D4 is triggered this is an orthonormal measurement to the in phase/out of phase diffraction patterns, and will provide us no data to help us sort of the two diffraction patterns. Conclusion Notice, I don’t need to talk about wave collapse, quantum erasure or anything of the sort. My two simple rules fully explain the observed results with absolutely no need to understand how nature enforces these rules across a space-time separation. Our actual measured results remain independent, and we only learn a bit more about the system later, when we compare the results of measuring the same thing in different ways. response.answer_text: Entanglement is a fanciful and entirely misleading term for the ordinary undirected time characteristic of all time-symmetric determinate systems: basically all fundamental physics since Galileo and Newton. Isolated systems with only a few degrees of freedom display undirected time: there's no before and after, so no concept of communication: all system information is available at every moment of the system's existence. There is no such thing as communication and no need for communication. The directed time of our experience is a direct consequence of the extreme asymmetry in the temporal evolution of our universe. Any system with enough degrees of freedom to support unique entropy, like us, is bound to an Arrow of Time pointed in the direction its entropy increases. Much has been learned and will continue to be learned from studying small isolated systems: they're not entangled, they're just isolated. They become entangled when they lose isolation and start interacting with their Arrow-entangled surroundings. Schrodinger got it exactly backwards when he coined the term in 1935! If you want more details, you might find my answers to What is quantum entanglement? and What is the "arrow of time"? of interest. The 2nd link addresses "Why does the entropy of everything big enough to have a definite entropy increase in the same direction in time?"

This is a very deep question. In quantum physics, measurements are subject to two types of uncertainty:  Uncertainty due to the fact that you don't know the state of your 'random' particle.Uncertainty due to the fact that the state of a quantum system does not uniquely determine all the measurements.The statistics of your measurements (including both types of uncertainty) can be characterized using a single mathematical object called the density matrix. Given your density matrix, you can predict the statistics for the outcome of your measurements. There are two key words in your question. These are "a particle", which means a single (only one) particle, and "at random", which means that you don't know anything about the state of the particle.  Let's look at the "at random" first. This means that you know nothing about the state of your particle. This state is called "totally mixed" and the density matrix is the identity matrix (up to a multiplicative constant). This means that you cannot predict anything about measurements done on the particle. Any outcome is possible and the results will tell you very little about the state of the particle. This is true even if you have many particles to measure on (provided that each of your random particles is different), because you will not be able to distinguish between the different types of uncertainty. Now imagine that the particles are not chosen at random from an unknown sample, but that you are guaranteed that all the particles have been subject to the same preparation, and have not been exposed to any type of interaction with the environment that could affect their coherent state.  In this case, you will be able to tell if the particles are entangled if you have many of them and can afford to do do many measurements and calculate statistics. There are three crucial aspects that allow you to do so:  You can (approximately) reconstruct the density matrix of a particle if you have many equally-prepared particles and can do measurements on many of them. This is called a state tomography.By looking at the density matrix, you can distinguish between "quantum uncertainty" and "uncertainty due to the fact that you don't know the state of the particle". This you can do mathematically by calculating the trace of the density matrix squared. If this value is one (accounting for measurement uncertainties), then the system is not entangled. If this value is smaller than one, then the system is entangled.If your particle is entangled to some external object, it looks like it has "uncertainty due to the fact that you don't know the state of the particle". This is because the state of the particle is correlated to something external that you don't have access to (*). In fact, the presence of this type of uncertainty is a means to characterize the amount of entanglement that a system has (Even though there is no such thing as an accepted universal measure of entanglement that works in all cases). Note: All this discussion assumes that the state of one of your particles can be described by a vector from a 2D Hilbert space. This is typically the case studied in quantum information. I believe the conclusions are general but they might not be if your state is described by an infinitely-dimensional Hilbert space. (*) There is a trick done in quantum information that exploits exactly that. The trick is called a purification. You can model a particle that you know nothing about by assuming that it's a particle that you know a lot about but that it's entangled to something else.

A (perfectly) entangled state is such that two degrees of freedom are correlated, e.g. the spins of two different electrons are such that if one has spin up the other has spin down and vice versa. This implies that the spin of particle one is completely unknown. Suppose the electrons are separated, so that one is kept by Alice and the other by Bob. If Alice measures the spin of her electron, the direction of the spin of Bob’s electron is immediately certain. If Bob measures the spin of his electron he will the value up or down. From that he cannot deduce wether Alice has measured her spin or not.If he knows that Alice has measured on her electron, either due to some previous agreed plan or he got a message from Alice, then he can learn which value Alice got in her measurement. However, that cannot serve as a message to Bob from Alice as she cannot control which value up or down she will get. That implies that Alice cannot control what result Bob will get. The result of Bob’s measurement cannot serve as a message from Alice as she cannot control it.In none of the two cases the entanglement allows for any message to be sent. A crucial point her is that Bob cannot sit and see how the spin of his electron changes from uncertain value to certain. His measurement is a momentary event that he has to decide when to do it. When it is done, the value becomes certain. If he measures before Alice, he has destroyed Alice possibility to influence the state of his electron.

You might think, “OK, we can’t transfer information using only one photon, but since a group of entangled photons behave differently to what they otherwise would have done without measurements being made on their entangled pairs, couldn’t that be used to transfer information?” But in fact, it can’t; we have no way of knowing in advance how they would have behaved without observations being made on their pairs (thanks John Gould for putting this rather nicely in our conversation). It’s only when we bring together the two sets of measurements that we can tell entanglement was a factor at all. That is, if A measures her particle in state 1 at precisely noon in USA, she knows that B in India will also measure his particle to be in state 1, whether he’s in Delhi, Mumbai, or on 55 Cancri(Just kidding). If you had simply measured the distant particle to be +1 or -1, then your measurement, here on Earth, of either -1 or +1 (respectively) would give you information about the particle located light years away. But by forcing that distant particle to be +1 or -1, that means, no matter the outcome, your particle here on Earth has a 50/50 shot of being +1 or -1, with no bearing on the particle so many light years distant. No, since neither party has control over the outcomes of the measurements. However, in quantum cryptography, having separated entangled qubits allows two parties to establish a perfect shared secret key, which one party can use as a one time pad to encrypt a message and send it over a classical channel. Now, does the transmitted information reside in the classical encrypted signal (which is pure noise without the key) or in the key (which is pure noise without the signal)? Of course, it is the former, because that is the only channel in which information is actually transmitted, even if the information is effectively unintelligible. In the latter, nothing is transmitted. Both parties merely have access to a non-local entropy source, i.e. a source of randomness that lives in two places at once.

Transfer of information requires a sending and a receiving of the information. The sending must occur prior to the receiving. In all entanglement situations there is a perfect symmetry between the ends of the entanglement. It is literally impossible for one end to be sending and another receiving. To some observers the first end is prior to the second end in time. To other equally valid observers the second end is prior to the first end in time. Neither one can unambiguously be the sending or the receiving end. No sending, no receiving, no transfer of information.

Right now all the technology can do is to send one entangled photon at a time over a channel - through fiber optics over a short distance and through free space optics over a distance of 100 kilometers or so. But even though the band width is very small the information sent via quantum entangled photons is completely secure. If someone tries to break into this channel, it'll be immediately detected. So currently a quantum entangled channel is being used for only one purpose - to generate and distribute a public key for public key encryption based communication protocol. One needs to keep in mind that although the wave function collapse of 2 maximally entangled particles happens instantaneously by classical measurement, the causality cannot be violated. The information transfer across such a channel is always going to be at a speed less than that of light.

Short answer: No.Long answer: Interactions with one of the two entangled particles causes it to randomly change change state; let's use spin for example. While a change of state of one particle leads to the instantaneous and opposite change of state of the other particle. A measurement at either end will randomize the system yet again, making it impossible to gather genuine information. Let's say person A has a particle entangled with a particle at person B. Person A interacts with his particle, measuring it to be spin up. Therefore, particle at B is spin down. But, when person B measures particle B, he changes the system's state again, with a 50% chance he reads his particle as up or down. In a sense any information you would want to send is lost in randomization.

Today, particles have been teleported several hundred kilometers away, but not physically. Instead of physically moving the particle to a destination, it is instead recreated elsewhere, while the original is altered. In contrast, sci-fi teleportation involves physically sending something, like a human being, to a predetermined location. While the technology in individual films vary, in many this is done by scanning a person’s body perfectly, down to the body’s sub-atomic particles’ quantum states, and then dematerializing that person and sending the scanned information to be rematerialized or reconstructed back into that original person somewhere else.
